u

th
hir Ma
tie
and yet I

rs

rs

Yo
r
next letter was of the sixt, By w
ch

of certeine letters written from
e College of the Cardinalls uppon
e deathe
of the

o
n of the Common Cawse taken in hand by the Popish faction and
the league: But nowe at this time at the writinge hereof will unders-
tand that theare is a newe
Pope
chosen, whoe was the Cardinal S
t
Quat[ro]
a person greatlie desired by the Spanish faction, and yet most perticulerly
addicted to the Duke of Parma, having been first made Cardinall by the
howse of Farnese./.
Yo
r
next letter and last, is of the xj
th
of this moneth, whearein yowe
doe discover sum dowbt howe the matter shall be carried that is in hand
betwixt the Empero
rs
Ambassado
rs

Treatie of a Peace, and w
th

r

of a writing devised by yo
r

yowe from thence to the said Ambassado
rs
, wheareof, and of yo
r
l
re
conteining both matter of great weight I made hir Ma
tie
well ac-
quainted, and she communicating the same seriouslie w
th
hir
Counsell
commaunded mee to lett yowe knowe, that she liked verie well of

the Care yowe tooke of this matter, and of the substance of the
reasons conteined in yo
r
purposed letter: but yet after she had well
weighed the Circumstances and caringe thereof she resolved that yt
showld not be sent by yowe, not for mislikinge of the reasons thearein
but for that yt cowld not be thowght convenient that yowe being hir
s
rvant, so neare at hand unto hir, showld write such a l
re
of soe
great moment in yo
r
owne name w
th
owt hir avowing thereof,
w
ch
whearein she might not convenientlie deale, except she weare made
a partie theareto, either from the Empero
r
, or from his Ambassado
rs
:
Nevertheles she requireth yowe to use all the good meanes yowe can both
privatlie and publicquelie according to yo
r
discretion that the States
Generall, or the
Counsell of States
, maie alledge sum just reasons to
differe this Treatie thowgh yt be not to refuse or reject yt: for w
ch
purpose hir Ma
tie
thinketh ther two reasons heareafter followinge accompa-
nied w
th
sum others, maie justlie suffice, to putt of the Treatie./
The first is, w
ch
alreadie hath been remembred, and maie be justlie re-
newed, that the States cannot in reason nor in polecie contrarie to their
Contract w
th
hir Ma
tie
, treate w
th
anie Prince, w
th
owt hir consent
by whome theie have been hitherto favorablie protected in the mainten
a
ce
of their libertie, and w
th
whome and the States of hir Cuntrie, theie
and their Forefathers have by spetiall Treaties and Bondes, been
bownd for mutuall defence: and therefore w
th
owt rejecting to treate
of Peace, theie maie require that hir Ma
tie
maie be sollicited & moved
to Consent theareto, wheareunto theie maie affirme hir Ma
tie
did showe
hir self willing in the yeare of
1588
when she was greatlie abused
offering a Treatie of Peace, w
th
one hand, and the invasion of the
Realme w
th
an other./.
A second reason maie be justlie alleged that wheare they are offred in
wordes from the Ambassado
rs
to have the libertie of Relligion grawnted
them, contrarie to all former proceading
of the
K. of Spaigne
, theie
can noe waies hope to have that offer performed and confirmed to them
considering yt is manifestlie seen that the K. of Spaigne onelie for
pretence of matter of Relligion invadeth at this present the
Frenche
K
. soe as whilest he shall continue that Co
r
se towardes a Soveraine K.
over whome he can challenge noe au
c
tie, as to make warre for collo
r
of Relligion, theare is noe hope to be had, that he will yeld libertie

to others over whome he pretendeth a Soveraine rule at the least he
will never continewe the same: and therefore untill yt maie appeare
that he shall alter his disposic
o
n in that behalf towardes the Frenche
K. and his Cuntrie, noe man can conceave hope that he will performe
that w
ch
owtwardlie is offred unto thos from whome he maie easelie
w
th
drawe his grawnt when he shall have by collo
r
of peace, disha-
bled them to mainteine themselves for enjoieng of such thing
as shall
be grawnted unto them. And in this sort hir Ma
tie
would have yo
u
to impresse thes and such like reasons to putt of this Treatie at
this time, w
th
owt gevinge Cawse to the Ambassado
rs
to conceave that
theie doe refuse to herken to peace, a thinge much desyred of them, and
onelie wantinge for lack of good assurance./
One other yo
r
privatt letter of the same date of the xj
th
of Novemb
r
was also read by hir Ma
tie
hir self, conteininge yo
r
privat request
to mee to move hir Ma
tie
to grawnt yowe license to returne, uppon
such reasons as are conteined in yo
r
letter, w
ch
hir Ma
tie
said she
cowld not denie but weare reasonable, but yet she cowld not
sodenlie determine, spetiallie before this next springe to revoke yo
u
havinge not determined wheare to find one fitt to succeade yowe.
And so hir Ma
tie
willed mee to advertise yo
u
, and require yowe to
take sum patience for the time./ And if in the meane time I can
anie waies devise howe to find owt a man sufficieint to succeade
yowe, I will not forgett to sollicite the same unto hir Ma
tie
./
And
soe having by this one letter heaped up an awnsweare to divers of
yo
rs
, I praie yowe to excuse mee for anie larger writing at
this time being neither at good leisure, nor in good healthe, as I
dowbt not but such as can from hence unto yowe, can make report.
From the Co
r
t at Whitehall this xx
th
of November.
1591
.
Yo
r
vearie Lovinge frend./
